message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fever, rash, and subcutaneous nodules indicate acute rheumatic fever, which is a Type II hypersensitivity reaction. Goodpasture syndrome is also a Type II hypersensitivity reaction, making it the correct answer. asthma and contact dermatitis are Type I hypersensitivity reactions, while osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones.

The symptoms suggest that the patient may have developed acute rheumatic fever, which is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to an untreated streptococcal infection. This type of hypersensitivity reaction is also seen in Goodpasture syndrome, which is an autoimmune disease that affects the kidneys and lungs. Asthma and contact dermatitis are not related to this type of hypersensitivity, and osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder that affects bone growth and is not related to immune hypersensitivity.
